contactUtilizationMethod: Grip the knife’s handle near its tip using a pen-style hold; the slightly rounded metal handle approximates marker girth. Trace imagined lines on the table with the blunt end to simulate marker strokes, benefiting from the handle’s cool, rigid feel and low inertia.
expectedHapticFeedback: As the marker glides across the paper, the user feels steady, consistent drag - a smooth but noticeable resistance that provides tactile confirmation the marker is making contact.
physicalSubstrateObject: yellow and green rectangular kitchen sponge
substrateUtilizationMethod: Place the sponge flat on the table with its yellow foam side facing up. Write over that surface with the knife tip using light pressure. The fine, closed-cell foam skin offers a uniform, gentle drag and a hint of spring, recreating the smooth slide and subtle give felt when a marker travels over thick sketch paper.

physicalSubstrateObject: small black portable electric fan

physicalSubstrateObject: yellow snack pack with Japanese text and peanuts illustration
substrateUtilizationMethod: Place the unopened snack pack flat on the table and smooth it with the hand to remove large wrinkles. Glide the knife tip across the printed plastic film. The thin, crinkly surface generates light but consistent drag—comparable to writing on a single sheet of loose paper—while the inner contents create a slight cushion that prevents slipping.

physicalSubstrateObject: white ping pong ball
substrateUtilizationMethod: Wedge the ping-pong ball against the table’s corner or cup it lightly with the non-dominant hand so it stays still. Trace small circular strokes on the ball’s matte plastic shell with the knife tip. The fine, slightly roughened surface finish supplies a gentle, uniform drag reminiscent of marker nib on thick drawing paper, ideal for practicing curved lines or signatures.
